His one fatal error lay in the unguarded entry into the defile of Trasimene, where his warier rival closed the trap upon him. Aristocratic writers may have gladly taken him as a soapegoat, imagining the neglect of sacred forms as a partial cause of the disaster, and exaggerating the rashness and in- capacity of the champion of the commone, just as modern critice may have dwelt too fondly on his fanoied virtues be- cause the nobles of his own day hated and maligned him.
